          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');

Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. \r\n \r\nDuring this CrowdCast, you will learn SlideshowScreen_withSections__cJqYu"><!--$--><div class="metadata Metadata_root__EZem9" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h1__3k7S2 title Title_root__svkHQ">CrowdCasts Monthly: You Have an Adversary Problem</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2013-10-16 14:09:38 UTC">Oct 16, 2013</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">6 likes</span><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">21,334<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="CrowdStrike" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-CrowdStrike-48x48.jpg?cb=1523357406" alt="CrowdStrike" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>CrowdStrike</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">You Have an Adversary Problem. Who&#x27;s Targeting You and Why? 
 
Nation-States, Hacktivists, Industrial Spies, and Organized Criminal Groups are attacking your enterprise on a daily basis. Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. 
 
During this CrowdCast, you will learn how to:

    Incorporate Actionable Intelligence into your existing enterprise security infrastructure 
    Quickly understand the capabilities and artifacts of targeted attacked tradecraft 
    Gain insight into the motivations and intentions of targeted attackers
    Make informed decisions based off of specific threat intelligence
</p></div><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_more__ChrRK" data-testid="button" aria-label="Read more" data-cy="read-more-button"><span>Read more</span></button></div></div><div class="MetadataToolbar_root__x4cNG metadata-toolbar" data-cy="slideshow-toolbar"><div 4

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

Adversary Categorization
CATEGORIZATION| Adversary Groups

1

Tactics, Techniques, and Practices

2

Never assume relationships exist
Between indicators

3

Recognize adversaries are constantly changing

4

But RECOGNIZE they are HUMAN

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY

1

INTELLIGENCE

Understand the adversaries targeting your
Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

2

Build appropriate defenses to counter/detect
these adversaries

3

Perform other security practices from an
Adversary-centric perspective
Pen Testing (Red Team)
Security Operations Brieﬁngs
Log Review

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" APT 14 and Aluminium. It targets maritime operations, aerospace, defense, and government sectors in countries like Australia, Germany, Sweden, UK, and USA. Tools used include Gh0st RAT, Poison Ivy, and Torn RAT. The group is believed to be sponsored by China&#x27;s PLA Navy and engages in cyber espionage to support its strategic interests in the South China Sea region.</span></div></div><div class="" Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Threat Hunting with Splunk for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Splunk">Splunk</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document provides an overview of threat hunting using Splunk. It begins with an introduction to threat hunting and why it is important. The presentation then discusses key building blocks for driving threat hunting maturity, including search and visualization, data enrichment, ingesting data sources, and applying machine learning. It provides examples of internal data sources that can be used for hunting like IP addresses, network artifacts, DNS, and endpoint data. The presentation demonstrates hunting using the Microsoft Sysmon endpoint agent, walking through an example attack scenario matching the Cyber Kill Chain framework. It shows how to investigate a potential compromise by searching across web, DNS, proxy, firewall, and endpoint data in Splunk to trace suspicious activity back to a specific user.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs). It begins by defining APTs and noting some common misconceptions about them. It then discusses notable APT attacks from 2003 to 2017. Finally, it outlines the typical lifecycle of an APT attack, including preparation such as researching targets, acquiring tools, and testing for detection, as well as the intrusion deployment phase.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber threat intelligence: maturity and metrics</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber threat intelligence: maturity and metrics for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd5na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd5na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd5na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MarkArena">Mark Arena</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From SANS Cyber Threat Intelligence Summit 2016. What are the characteristics of a mature cyber threat intelligence program, and how do you develop meaningful metrics? Traditionally, intelligence has been about providing decision
support to executives whilst the field of cyber threat intelligence supports this customer, and network defenders, who have different requirements. By using the intelligence cycle, this talk will
seek to help attendees understand how they can identify what a mature intelligence program looks like and the steps to take their program to the next level.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-5" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R16na7f6:" popovertarget=":R16na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R16na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/6-steps-for-operationalizing-threat-intelligence/63848095"><span class="sr-only">6 Steps for Operationalizing Threat Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="6 Steps for Operationalizing Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/6stepsforoperationalizingthreatintelligence-v2-160708144438-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="6 Steps for Operationalizing Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/6stepsforoperationalizingthreatintelligence-v2-160708144438-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">6 Steps for Operationalizing Threat Intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save 6 Steps for Operationalizing Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd6na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd6na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd6na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Forsythe_Technology">Sirius</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The best form of defense against cyber attacks and those who perpetrate them is to know about them. Collaborative defense has become critical to IT security, and sharing threat intelligence is a force multiplier. But for many organizations, good quality intelligence is hard to come by.

Commercial threat intelligence technology and services can help enterprises arm themselves with the strategic, tactical and operational insights they need to identify and respond to global threat activity, and integrate intelligence into their security programs.

Threat intelligence sources have varying levels of relevance and context, and there are concerns about data quality and redundancy, shelf life, public/private data sharing, and threat intelligence standards. However, if processed and applied properly, threat intelligence provides a way for organizations to get the insight they need into attackers’ plans, prioritize and respond to threats, shorten the time between attack and detection, and focus staff efforts and decision-making.

View to learn: 

--The difference between threat information and threat intelligence.
--Available sources of intelligence and how to determine if they apply to your business.
--Key steps for preparing to ingest threat information and turn it into intelligence.
--How to derive useful data that helps you achieve your business goals.
--Tools that are available to make collaboration easier.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R17na7f6:" popovertarget=":R17na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R17na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/the-cyber-threat-intelligence-matrix/67745151"><span class="sr-only">The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:6" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd7na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd7na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd7na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/FrodeHommedal">Frode Hommedal</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As we get to know what life in the digital domain is like, one of the revelations we&#x27;ve had is that many large and plenty of smaller organisations are targets of espionage, of the nefarious APT.

During the last decade, it has become gospel to wait, watch, analyse and learn if you detect such an attacker in your infrastructure. Why? Because you get one chance to do the eviction of the attacker right. And if you fail, all your efforts will eventually have been for nothing.

But for how long should you wait and watch? When have you watched long enough? When have you learned enough? And how do you make that decision?

That is the challenge I hope the Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix can help you face in a more structured manner.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R18na7f6:" popovertarget=":R18na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R18na7f6"><a ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac..." loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd8na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd8na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd8na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd8na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd8na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Jason Wood and Justin Swisher, CrowdStrike

When it comes to understanding and tracking intrusion tradecraft, security teams must have the tools and processes that allow the mapping of hands-on adversary tradecraft. Doing this enables your team to both understand the adversaries and attacks you currently see and observe how these adversaries and attacks evolve over time. This session will explore how a threat hunting team uses MITRE ATT&amp;CK to understand and categorize adversary activity. The team will demonstrate how threat hunters map ATT&amp;CK TTPs by showcasing a recent interactive intrusion against a Linux endpoint and how the framework allowed for granular tracking of tradecraft and enhanced security operations. They will also take a look into the changes in the Linux activity they have observed over time, using the ATT&amp;CK navigator to compare and contrast technique usage. This session will provide insights into how we use MITRE ATT&amp;CK as a powerful resource to track intrusion tradecraft, identify adversary trends, and prepare for attacks of the future.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R18na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-8" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R19na7f6:" popovertarget=":R19na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R19na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/global-cyber-threat-intelligence/62868534"><span class="sr-only">Global Cyber Threat Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:8" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ntti3">NTT Innovation Institute Inc.</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Recently, NTT published the Global Threat Intelligence Report 2016 (GTIR). This year’s report focused both on the changes in threat trends and on how security organizations around the world can use the kill chain to help defend the enterprise. 

Turning threat intelligence data from multiple sources into actionable, contextual information is a challenge faced by many organizations today. The Global Threat Intelligence Platform provides increased efficiency, reduces risks and focuses on global coverage with accurate and up-to-date threat intelligence.

This presentation was given at Carnegie Mellon University by Kenji Takahashi, VP of Product Management, Security at NTT Innovation Institute. </span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19na7f6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdcna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdcna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Lex Crumpton leads MITRE&#x27;s defensive ATT&amp;CK efforts. In 2021, they added data sources and detections for monitoring processes interacting with LSASS.exe and detecting credential dumping tools. In 2022, they plan to add more detections and develop the Cyber Analytic Repository to share analytic knowledge. Crumpton invites attendees to learn more about defensive ATT&amp;CK on their website and contact them directly with any other questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1cna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1cna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-12" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1dna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1dna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1dna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/putting-mitre-attck-into-action-with-what-you-have-where-you-are/143650354"><span class="sr-only">Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:12" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are" Action with What You Have, Where You Are</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbddna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbddna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbddna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/KatieNickels">Katie Nickels</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document provides an overview of Katie Nickels&#x27; presentation on putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into action using available resources. Some key points include:
- MITRE ATT&amp;CK is a knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations. 
- It can be used for detection, assessment, threat intelligence, and adversary emulation.
- For detection, ATT&amp;CK can help improve focus on post-exploit activity and track gaps/improvements in coverage over time. Existing data sources can be leveraged to detect techniques.
- For assessment and engineering, ATT&amp;CK can guide decisions around tool selection and help identify visibility and risk acceptance gaps.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/prachimishra31">Prachi Mishra</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cyber threat intelligence and collaborative threat intelligence. It provides an overview of malware trends, requirements for developing threat intelligence capabilities, and principles for managing threat intelligence proactively. The document advocates for a collaborative threat intelligence framework to enable preventative response by identifying and blocking known attackers across multiple organizations through automated and real-time threat information sharing. Standards and tools discussed include IODEF, CIF and how CIF can be used to gather, identify, respond to and mitigate threats based on indicators collected from various sources.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ena7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ena7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" Playbook</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdfna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdfna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Santiago Pontiroli and Dmitry Bestuzhev, Kaspersky

Financially motivated cyber-attacks thrive in emerging Latin American markets. However, there&#x27;s room for locally grown threat actors operating in the cyber espionage field as well. During the last decade, this includes but is not limited to Blind Eagle, Puppeteer, Machete, Poseidon, and others. We also saw foreign operations targeting specific assets in Latin America, still connected to certain regional sources.

Since the threat actors&#x27; origin, culture, and language is often different, it&#x27;s not uncommon for tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) to present marked differences. As a result of our regional expertise and experience, we created MITRE&#x27;s ATT&amp;CK play-by-play mappings to help other analysts understand regional actors. If you are interested in threat intelligence and what&#x27;s going on in Latin America, this presentation is for you. Our work is based only on real-world attackers and their operations, including those not publicly known, such as COVID-19 Machete&#x27;s targeted campaign.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1fna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1fna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" program that supports the business, not just the SOC</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1gna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" aria-controls=":Rbdhna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdhna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdhna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdhna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdhna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Gain in-depth information on the massive WannaCry ransomware attack

On Friday, May 12, the WannaCry ransomware variant swept the globe. In a short period of time, WannaCry (also known as Wanna Decryptor and WannaCryptor) infected over 230,000 systems in 150 countries. It was a particularly effective piece of malware because it not only encrypted data and held it for ransom, but it also spread like wildfire to other systems. Entire organizations found themselves looking at a ransom note on their screens and wondering what to do next.

As the situation continues to unfold, please join us as Adam Myers, VP of Threat Intelligence at CrowdStrike, presents an in-depth look at the WannaCry ransomware.

Register for this webcast to learn:
-A complete technical understanding of the WannaCry threat
-What analysts were seeing on the day of the WannaCry outbreak
-How to prevent WannaCry infections and protect against ransomware going forward</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/using-attack-to-create-cyber-dbts-for-nuclear-power-plants/241296785"><span class="sr-only">Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a alt="Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckcon-final1-210113202045-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdina7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdina7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdina7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdina7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdina7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour December 2020

By Jacob Benjamin, Principal Industrial Consultant Dragos, INL, &amp; University of Idaho 

Design Basis Threat (DBT) is concept introduced by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). It is a profile of the type, composition, and capabilities of an adversary. DBT is the key input nuclear power plants use for the design of systems against acts of radiological sabotage and theft of special nuclear material. The NRC expects its licensees, nuclear power plants, to demonstrate that they can defend against the DBT. Currently, cyber is included in DBTs simply as a prescribed list of IT centric security controls. Using MITRE’s ATT&amp;CK framework, Cyber DBTs can be created that are specific to the facility, its material, or adversary activities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ina7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ina7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1jna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1jna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1jna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-threat-intelligence-225070562/225070562"><span class="sr-only">Cyber Threat Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/cyberti-200127133007-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/cyberti-200127133007-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Threat Intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdjna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdjna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdjna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdjna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdjna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ZaiffiEhsan">ZaiffiEhsan</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Cyber threat intelligence involves collecting, analyzing, and sharing information about threats to help organizations assess risks and defend themselves. It follows principles like being centralized, objective, and continuous. The Structured Threat Information Expression (STIX) framework allows sharing threat data consistently between organizations using common language. Intrusion detection systems monitor networks and systems for malicious activity, using either signature-based methods to detect known threats or anomaly-based methods to find unknown behaviors.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1jna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-19" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1kna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1kna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1kna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cloud-Enabled: The Future of Endpoint Security</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cloud-Enabled: The Future of Endpoint Security for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdkna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdkna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdkna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdkna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdkna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As the cost and complexity of deploying and maintaining on-premises security continues to rise, many endpoint security providers have embraced the cloud as the ideal way to deliver their solutions. Yet, incorporating cloud services into legacy architectures limits their ability to fully engage the tremendous power the cloud offers.

CrowdStrike Falcon recognized the value of cloud-delivery from the beginning, developing architecture built from the ground up to take full advantage of the cloud. CrowdStrike’s cloud-powered endpoint security not only ensures rapid deployment and infinite scalability, it increases your security posture by enabling real-time advanced threat protection across even the largest, distributed enterprises.

In this CrowdCast, Jackie Castelli, Sr. Product Manager will discuss:

•The advantages of endpoint protection purpose-built for the cloud – why it allows you to take full advantage of the cloud’s power
•The common concerns organizations face when evaluating cloud-based endpoint security - can privacy and control be assured?
•Real-world examples demonstrating the unique advantages    offered by CrowdStrike Falcon’s innovative cloud-powered platform</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1kna7f6:" popover="auto" By Lauren Brennan, GuidePoint Security

Evaluating the maturity of your security operations program can be complex and challenging.  From choosing the right framework to use, to understanding all aspects of how people, processes, and technologies can cohesively operate to grow your SOC, evaluating your security operations is crucial. This presentation will discuss how to evaluate your security operations program using the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework and talk about best practices for evaluations. We will explore how to identify gaps in your operations and improve your overall security posture with foundational activities. Attendees can expect to learn practical tips for leveraging the MITRE framework as well as actionable takeaways for evaluating and improving their own security operations.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1mna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1mna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" understanding of cyber threats through ATT&amp;CK threat sightings. It describes the AC3 methodology for documenting threat actor tactics, techniques, and procedures with full context and observables. Different levels of abstraction and tools are used to translate threat sightings into various formats to ensure understanding across audiences. Maintaining defensive playbooks adapted from threat sightings helps continuous understanding and improvement of defenses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1nna7f6:" popover="auto" and answers of some Q such as; What is Threat Hunting?, What is the Importance of Threat Hunting, and How it can be start....Bla..Bla..Bla...</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1pna7f6:" An Insight Into Highly ...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Would you Rather Have Telemetry into 2 Attacks or 20? An Insight Into Highly ... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdrna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdrna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdrna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdrna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdrna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Jonny Johnson, Red Canary and Olaf Hartong, FalconForce

As defenders, we often find ourselves wanting &quot;more&quot; data. But why? Will this new data provide a lot of value or is it for a very niche circumstance? How many attacks does it apply to? Are we leveraging previous data sources to their full capability? Within this talk, Olaf and Jonny will walk through different data sources they leverage more than most when analyzing data within environments, why they do, and what these data sources do and can provide in terms of value to a defender.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1rna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1rna7f6"></div><div class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In today’s threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div landscape in 2013. slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Global Cyber Threat Intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Global Cyber Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd1c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd1c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ntti3">NTT Innovation Institute Inc.</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Recently, NTT published the Global Threat Intelligence Report 2016 (GTIR). This year’s report focused both on the changes in threat trends and on how security organizations around the world can use the kill chain to help defend the enterprise. 

Turning threat intelligence data from multiple sources into actionable, contextual information is a challenge faced by many organizations today. The Global Threat Intelligence Platform provides increased efficiency, reduces risks and focuses on global coverage with accurate and up-to-date threat intelligence.

This presentation was given at Carnegie Mellon University by Kenji Takahashi, VP of Product Management, Security at NTT Innovation Institute. </span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R12c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R12c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R12c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/threatbased-adversary-emulation-with-mitre-attck/113694290"><span class="sr-only">Threat-Based Adversary Emulation with MITRE ATT&amp;CK</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Lex Crumpton leads MITRE&#x27;s defensive ATT&amp;CK efforts. In 2021, they added data sources and detections for monitoring processes interacting with LSASS.exe and detecting credential dumping tools. In 2022, they plan to add more detections and develop the Cyber Analytic Repository to share analytic knowledge. Crumpton invites attendees to learn more about defensive ATT&amp;CK on their website and contact them directly with any other questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14c9jnf6:" popover="auto" Where You Are</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img Action with What You Have, Where You Are</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd5c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/KatieNickels">Katie Nickels</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document provides an overview of Katie Nickels&#x27; presentation on putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into action using available resources. Some key points include:
- MITRE ATT&amp;CK is a knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations. 
- It can be used for detection, assessment, threat intelligence, and adversary emulation.
- For detection, ATT&amp;CK can help improve focus on post-exploit activity and track gaps/improvements in coverage over time. Existing data sources can be leveraged to detect techniques.
- For assessment and engineering, ATT&amp;CK can guide decisions around tool selection and help identify visibility and risk acceptance gaps.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="sr-only">Cyber Threat Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Threat Intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd6c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/prachimishra31">Prachi Mishra</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cyber threat intelligence and collaborative threat intelligence. It provides an overview of malware trends, requirements for developing threat intelligence capabilities, and principles for managing threat intelligence proactively. The document advocates for a collaborative threat intelligence framework to enable preventative response by identifying and blocking known attackers across multiple organizations through automated and real-time threat information sharing. Standards and tools discussed include IODEF, CIF and how CIF can be used to gather, identify, respond to and mitigate threats based on indicators collected from various sources.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R17c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R17c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R17c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/the-attck-latin-american-apt-playbook/251521527"><span class="sr-only">The ATT&amp;CK Latin American APT Playbook</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:6" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="The ATT&amp;CK Latin American APT Playbook" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/theattcklatinamericanaptplaybook-220406000927-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/theattcklatinamericanaptplaybook-220406000927-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">The ATT&amp;CK Latin American APT Playbook</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save The ATT&amp;CK Latin American APT Playbook for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd7c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd7c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd7c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Santiago Pontiroli and Dmitry Bestuzhev, Kaspersky

Financially motivated cyber-attacks thrive in emerging Latin American markets. However, there&#x27;s room for locally grown threat actors operating in the cyber espionage field as well. During the last decade, this includes but is not limited to Blind Eagle, Puppeteer, Machete, Poseidon, and others. We also saw foreign operations targeting specific assets in Latin America, still connected to certain regional sources.

Since the threat actors&#x27; origin, culture, and language is often different, it&#x27;s not uncommon for tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) to present marked differences. As a result of our regional expertise and experience, we created MITRE&#x27;s ATT&amp;CK play-by-play mappings to help other analysts understand regional actors. If you are interested in threat intelligence and what&#x27;s going on in Latin America, this presentation is for you. Our work is based only on real-world attackers and their operations, including those not publicly known, such as COVID-19 Machete&#x27;s targeted campaign.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R18c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R18c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R18c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-threat-intelligence-building-and-maturing-an-intelligence-program-that-supports-the-business-not-just-the-soc/80090631"><span class="sr-only">Cyber Threat Intelligence: Building and maturing an intelligence program that...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence: Building and maturing an intelligence program that..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/anomalidetectpresentation-170923215218-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence: Building and maturing an intelligence program that..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/anomalidetectpresentation-170923215218-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Threat Intelligence: Building and maturing an intelligence program that...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi program that supports the business, not just the SOC</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-8" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R19c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R19c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R19c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:8" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">An Inside Look At The WannaCry Ransomware Outbreak</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save An Inside Look At The WannaCry Ransomware Outbreak for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd9c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd9c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd9c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd9c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd9c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Gain in-depth information on the massive WannaCry ransomware attack

On Friday, May 12, the WannaCry ransomware variant swept the globe. In a short period of time, WannaCry (also known as Wanna Decryptor and WannaCryptor) infected over 230,000 systems in 150 countries. It was a particularly effective piece of malware because it not only encrypted data and held it for ransom, but it also spread like wildfire to other systems. Entire organizations found themselves looking at a ransom note on their screens and wondering what to do next.

As the situation continues to unfold, please join us as Adam Myers, VP of Threat Intelligence at CrowdStrike, presents an in-depth look at the WannaCry ransomware.

Register for this webcast to learn:
-A complete technical understanding of the WannaCry threat
-What analysts were seeing on the day of the WannaCry outbreak
-How to prevent WannaCry infections and protect against ransomware going forward</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19c9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ac9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ac9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ac9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/using-attack-to-create-cyber-dbts-for-nuclear-power-plants/241296785"><span class="sr-only">Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:9" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants" alt="Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckcon-final1-210113202045-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Using ATTACK to Create Cyber DBTS for Nuclear Power Plants for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdac9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdac9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdac9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdac9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdac9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour December 2020

By Jacob Benjamin, Principal Industrial Consultant Dragos, INL, &amp; University of Idaho 

Design Basis Threat (DBT) is concept introduced by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). It is a profile of the type, composition, and capabilities of an adversary. DBT is the key input nuclear power plants use for the design of systems against acts of radiological sabotage and theft of special nuclear material. The NRC expects its licensees, nuclear power plants, to demonstrate that they can defend against the DBT. Currently, cyber is included in DBTs simply as a prescribed list of IT centric security controls. Using MITRE’s ATT&amp;CK framework, Cyber DBTs can be created that are specific to the facility, its material, or adversary activities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ac9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ac9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-10" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1bc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1bc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1bc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-threat-intelligence-225070562/225070562"><span class="sr-only">Cyber Threat Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:10" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/cyberti-200127133007-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/cyberti-200127133007-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Threat Intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdbc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdbc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdbc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdbc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdbc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ZaiffiEhsan">ZaiffiEhsan</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Cyber threat intelligence involves collecting, analyzing, and sharing information about threats to help organizations assess risks and defend themselves. It follows principles like being centralized, objective, and continuous. The Structured Threat Information Expression (STIX) framework allows sharing threat data consistently between organizations using common language. Intrusion detection systems monitor networks and systems for malicious activity, using either signature-based methods to detect known threats or anomaly-based methods to find unknown behaviors.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1bc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1bc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1cc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1cc9jnf6:" Endpoint Security</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As the cost and complexity of deploying and maintaining on-premises security continues to rise, many endpoint security providers have embraced the cloud as the ideal way to deliver their solutions. Yet, incorporating cloud services into legacy architectures limits their ability to fully engage the tremendous power the cloud offers.

CrowdStrike Falcon recognized the value of cloud-delivery from the beginning, developing architecture built from the ground up to take full advantage of the cloud. CrowdStrike’s cloud-powered endpoint security not only ensures rapid deployment and infinite scalability, it increases your security posture by enabling real-time advanced threat protection across even the largest, distributed enterprises.

In this CrowdCast, Jackie Castelli, Sr. Product Manager will discuss:

•The advantages of endpoint protection purpose-built for the cloud – why it allows you to take full advantage of the cloud’s power
•The common concerns organizations face when evaluating cloud-based endpoint security - can privacy and control be assured?
•Real-world examples demonstrating the unique advantages    offered by CrowdStrike Falcon’s innovative cloud-powered platform</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1cc9jnf6:" popover="auto" meet up</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dc9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Evaluating and Maturing Your SOC using MITRE ATT&amp;CK</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:13" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Grow Up! Evaluating and Maturing Your SOC using MITRE ATT&amp;CK" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/brennanpresentationgrowupevaluatingandmaturingyoursocwithmitreattck-231030001556-4a79a37c-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Grow Up! Evaluating and Maturing Your SOC using MITRE ATT&amp;CK" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/brennanpresentationgrowupevaluatingandmaturingyoursocwithmitreattck-231030001556-4a79a37c-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Grow Up! Evaluating and Maturing Your SOC using MITRE ATT&amp;CK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Grow Up! Evaluating and Maturing Your SOC using MITRE ATT&amp;CK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdec9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdec9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdec9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdec9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdec9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 4.0

By Lauren Brennan, GuidePoint Security

Evaluating the maturity of your security operations program can be complex and challenging.  From choosing the right framework to use, to understanding all aspects of how people, processes, and technologies can cohesively operate to grow your SOC, evaluating your security operations is crucial. This presentation will discuss how to evaluate your security operations program using the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework and talk about best practices for evaluations. We will explore how to identify gaps in your operations and improve your overall security posture with foundational activities. Attendees can expect to learn practical tips for leveraging the MITRE framework as well as actionable takeaways for evaluating and improving their own security operations.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ec9jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ec9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses using storytelling to increase understanding of cyber threats through ATT&amp;CK threat sightings. It describes the AC3 methodology for documenting threat actor tactics, techniques, and procedures with full context and observables. Different levels of abstraction and tools are used to translate threat sightings into various formats to ensure understanding across audiences. Maintaining defensive playbooks adapted from threat sightings helps continuous understanding and improvement of defenses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1fc9jnf6:" popover="auto"
